questions.question_text: Which of the following is true of Snowpipe via REST API? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Answer is C & D.

Not B as:

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/sql/create-pipe.html#usage-notes

All COPY INTO <table> copy options are supported except for the following:

FILES = ( 'file_name1' [ , 'file_name2', ... ] )

ON_ERROR = ABORT_STATEMENT

SIZE_LIMIT = num

PURGE = TRUE | FALSE (i.e. automatic purging while loading)

FORCE = TRUE | FALSE
C and D are correct

Selected Answer: CD
Correct Answer is CD

Correct answer:CD
since pipe is using serverless functionality

Selected Answer: CD
The correct options for what is true of Snowpipe via REST API are:

C. Snowflake automatically manages the compute required to execute the Pipe's COPY INTO commands
D. Snowpipe keeps track of which files it has loaded

Here's why the other options are not accurate:

A. You can only use it on Internal Stages: You can use Snowpipe via REST API with both Internal Stages (located within Snowflake storage) and External Stages (referencing data in external cloud storage providers like S3 or Azure Blob Storage).
B. All COPY INTO options are available during pipe creation: Not all COPY INTO options are available through the Snowpipe REST API for pipe creation. While the core functionality is supported, some advanced options might be limited through the API compared to directly using the COPY INTO command within Snowflake.

Selected Answer: CD
C & D:

Snowpipe uses Snowflake-provided compute resources:
https://docs.snowflake.com/user-guide/data-load-snowpipe-intro#calling-snowpipe-rest-endpoints

Selected Answer: BD
BD are correct
Answer is C & D.

Selected Answer: CD
Ans should be C & D

Selected Answer: CD
CD are correct answer

Selected Answer: CD
CD are correct

Selected Answer: CD
C&D is right
CD are correct
CD are correct answer

Selected Answer: CD
Snowpipe copy into has certain restrictions.
Answer C D
Should be C and D
Ans will be C & D

Selected Answer: CD
Agree with explanation by redsky0

choices.B: All COPY INTO options are available during pipe creation
choices.A: You can only use it on Internal Stages
choices.D: Snowpipe keeps track of which files it has loaded
choices.C: Snowflake automatically manages the compute required to execute the Pipe's COPY INTO commands

questions.question_text:
How can a Snowflake user access a JSON object, given the following table? (Choose two.)

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/querying-semistructured

Important

Regardless of which notation you use, the column name is case-insensitive but element names are case-sensitive. For example, in the following list, the first two paths are equivalent, but the third is not:

src:salesperson.name

SRC:salesperson.name

SRC:Salesperson.Name

Selected Answer: BD
correct
A is one of the correct

correct

questions.question_text: Which term is used to describe information about disk usage for operations where intermediate results cannot be accommodated in a Snowflake virtual warehouse memory?

choices.A: Clone the data from the production account to the non-production account.
choices.D: Create a reader account using the production account and link the reader account to the non-production account.
choices.C: Create a subscription in the production account and have it publish to the non-production account.
choices.B: Create a data share from the production account to the non-production account.

questions.question_text:
There are two Snowflake accounts in the same cloud provider region: one is production and the other is non-production.

How can data be easily transferred from the production account to the non-production account?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Across Account

Selected Answer: B
Can't clone data across accounts

Selected Answer: B
Cannot clone across accounts, hence B

correct
